DOCNAME: CASE OF E.L., R.L. AND J.O.-L. v. SWITZERLAND
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-2;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants are all NORP nationals who live in GPE . They are the widow , the son and the daughter of the late Mr L.

CARDINAL . Mr L. was the owner of a mail - order company . In DATE he declared certain moneys to the tax authorities ; he maintained that these were profits lawfully made in GPE from capital speculation and investments , and were not taxable in GPE .
CARDINAL . Mr L. died on DATE .
CARDINAL . The DATE period within which the applicants could have rejected the inheritance ( Articles CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Swiss Civil Code ) expired on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , having come to the conclusion – in the absence of vouchers supporting Mr L. 's allegations – that the moneys declared were in reality income generated by Mr L. 's mail - order firm which he had unlawfully failed to declare in GPE , initiated proceedings against the applicants for recovery of unpaid cantonal and federal taxes , and at the same time imposed fines for tax evasion .
CARDINAL . It appears that the applicants cooperated with the tax authorities , enabling them to make a correct assessment of the taxes due .
CARDINAL . The DATE 's file contains no information about any proceedings to contest the recovery of cantonal tax arrears or the related fine .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants appealed to ORG against the decision of CARDINAL DATE in so far as it related to direct federal taxes .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG gave its decision . It considered that the tax authorities had failed to prove that the moneys in question were undeclared taxable income , but found it established that Mr L. had deliberately failed to declare the interest received from it . Accordingly , it partly upheld the applicants ' appeal , significantly reducing the amount of back tax to be paid . It also reduced the fine to CARDINAL of the additional amount normally due in view of the fact that Mr L. had himself reported the moneys concerned to the authorities .
CARDINAL . ORG lodged an administrative - law appeal to ORG .
CARDINAL . The applicants filed a written defence arguing , inter alia , that it was contrary to LAW to impose a fine on the heirs of a taxpayer for tax evasion committed by the latter .
CARDINAL . ORG and ORG were invited to submit written comments pursuant to section CARDINAL of LAW .
ORG declined to do so . ORG expressed the opinion that the appeal should be dismissed .
CARDINAL . In a judgment delivered on CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld the appeal .

It held that ORG had erred in imposing the burden of proof on the tax authorities . Since their investigations had revealed prima facie evidence that Mr L. had been guilty of tax evasion , it had been for the applicants to demonstrate that the moneys in question had not in fact been undeclared taxable income . Since the applicants had not done so , the assessment of back taxation should be allowed to stand .

ORG rejected the suggestion that the imposition of a tax fine on the heirs of the taxpayer for tax evasion committed by the latter was contrary to LAW . After referring to its case - law , it went on to hold :

“ [ In earlier cases ORG ] has held that although the tax fine constituted a real penalty , it was directed at the deceased personally and not at the heirs ; the heirs were required , under LAW § CARDINAL of the Ordinance on Direct Federal Tax , only to ensure that the fine was paid and only up to the value of their share of the estate . That the fine was not directed at the heirs also appeared from the fact that the fine was determined in principle [ grundsätzlich ] according to the guilt of the deceased and the heirs could escape their liability by renouncing the inheritance . As ORG has held , the effect of the arrangement laid down in LAW § CARDINAL of the Ordinance on Direct Federal Tax – according to which in pending proceedings the heirs take the place of the deceased , and [ new ] proceedings were to be initiated and pursued against the heirs if the evasion was discovered only after the death of the deceased – is only that all cases are dealt with in the same way , irrespective of the time factor . ”
However , as the fine had to be determined anew , the case was referred back to ORG .
CARDINAL . The applicants applied to the ORG on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG gave a decision setting the fine at MONEY ( CHF ) , or PERCENT of the amount that would normally have been due , in view of the applicants ' basically cooperative attitude .

CARDINAL . The applicants lodged an administrative - law appeal to ORG on DATE . They produced , inter alia , medical evidence from which it appeared that in DATE of his life Mr L. had not been wholly responsible for his actions and they suggested that a fine of not MONEY CARDINAL,CARDINAL would be more appropriate to reflect his guilt .
ORG and ORG and ORG were invited to submit written comments , and they asked ORG to dismiss the appeal .

CARDINAL . In a judgment delivered on DATE ORG upheld the applicants ' appeal in so far as it was argued that the question of Mr L. 's diminished responsibility should have been considered and referred the case back to ORG for a second time .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG gave a decision in which it reduced the fine that would have been payable by Mr L. himself on the ground of his diminished responsibility , and in view of the applicants ' attitude set the final amount at PERCENT of that figure , or CHF CARDINAL,CARDINAL.CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . At the relevant time , tax evasion was punishable by a fine of CARDINAL times the amount evaded , the fine being payable in addition to the amount due ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Ordinance on Direct Federal Tax ) .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provided , inter alia :

“ If the evasion is discovered only after the death of the taxpayer , proceedings shall be brought against his heirs . Irrespective of personal guilt , the heirs shall be jointly liable for the deceased person 's evaded taxes and the fine incurred by him up to an amount not exceeding their share in the estate . ”
CARDINAL . According to Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Swiss Civil Code , an inheritance passes upon the death of the deceased .
CARDINAL . The relevant parts of LAW of the Swiss Civil Code provide :
“ CARDINAL . The heirs shall automatically acquire the entire estate as soon as it passes .

CARDINAL . Subject to the statutory exceptions , all claims and actions , property rights and other rights in rem and possessions of the deceased shall automatically pass to them , and they shall become personally liable for the deceased 's debts . ”

CARDINAL . Under LAW § CARDINAL of the Swiss Civil Code , the heirs have the right to renounce the inheritance which has devolved to them . The time - limit for so doing is DATE ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . It was open to the taxpayer to lodge an objection against an assessment of direct federal tax to the authority which had made it ( Article CARDINAL of the Ordinance on Direct Federal Tax ) .

CARDINAL . An appeal against the decision given in the objection proceedings lay to ORG ( Article CARDINAL of the Ordinance on Direct Federal Tax ) . ORG of the canton and the federal tax authorities could also bring such an appeal ( Article CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . An administrative - law appeal lies to ORG against the decision of ORG ( section CARDINAL ( e ) of LAW ) . Such an appeal may be lodged by both the tax debtor and the federal tax authorities ( LAW of the Ordinance on Direct Federal Tax ) .

CARDINAL . If ORG orders an exchange of written pleadings , it asks the authority which gave the decision to forward the case file ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) , at the same time inviting it to submit its comments in writing ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .

The cantonal authority which gave the last decision at cantonal level is also invited to comment ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) , as is the federal authority which would itself have been entitled to lodge an appeal ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . At the material time , section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of ORG made it possible for a CARDINAL - judge ORG to dismiss an administrative - law appeal as manifestly ill - founded without a hearing , provided that its decision was unanimous .
CARDINAL . Under Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW , the general provisions of the LAW apply to offences created by other federal laws unless the latter provide otherwise .
CARDINAL . Article QUANTITY CARDINAL of the Criminal Code provides that a fine lapses if the convicted person dies .
However , pursuant to LAW , LAW see paragraph CARDINAL above ) derogates from this principle as a lex specialis .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of ORG of DATE , in force since DATE , provides for the liability of heirs , inter alia , for any fines determined with legal force . According to section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) , the heirs shall not be so liable if the tax evasion proceedings are concluded after the death of the taxpayer , provided that the heirs themselves are guiltless and do what they can to enable the tax authorities to make a correct assessment .
